Since 2019, venture capital investment in digital health start-ups has seen exponential growth. Deals totaling $12.2 billion were announced in 2019, with the vast majority of that coming from venture capital firms. That number jumped to $17.6 billion in 2020, and some analysts have predicted it could reach as high as $20 billion in 2021.

However, despite the rapid growth of venture capital investment, the global economic downturn caused by the Covid-19 pandemic could force digital health companies to consider alternative sources of funding and exit options such as M&A in 2021.

According to Warburg Pincus Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer Kate Askew, M&A activity in the digital health sector could reach unprecedented levels in 2021.

“We’re starting to see some of the traditional corporate strategic investors, the Big Techs and some of the retail players really start to pay attention to digital health,” Askew said during a discussion at the JP Morgan Healthcare Conference. “And I think that’s going to be one of the primary drivers of M&A activity in 2021.”

Askew believes that the Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the use of digital health services, and that this increased usage could make digital health companies more attractive to strategic buyers.

“I think there’s going to be a very large wave of M&A that’s going to be driven by these corporate players as well as some of the traditional private equity firms,” Askew said.

She also believes that the high-valuations that digital health companies are commanding from venture capital firms could lead to more M&A activity as those companies look to make the most of their investments.

“The market is so crowded with digital health companies, many of which are commanding large valuations,” Askew said. “So I think that it’s likely that there are going to be some digital health players that are going to look to consolidate in the coming year.”

The coronavirus pandemic has forced people around the world to become more comfortable with using digital health services, which could spur even more M&A activity in 2021.

“We’re seeing an increased comfort level from consumers and providers when it comes to digital health services,” Askew said. “That could lead to a lot of M&A activity in the sector next year, as more traditional players look to get involved in the space.”

As more and more digital health services enter the market, Askew believes that companies are going to look for ways to differentiate themselves from the competition. That could mean acquiring other digital health companies in order to offer a more comprehensive suite of services.

“There’s a lot of interest in digital health services and companies are going to be looking for ways to stand out from the crowd,” Askew said. “That could mean looking to acquire other companies that are offering services or products that can help them do that.”

The recession could also lead to an uptick in M&A activity in the digital health sector, as companies look to bolster their balance sheets and cut costs.

“When you’re trying to cut costs and preserve cash, one of the first things you’re going to do is look to consolidation,” Askew said. “That could mean making acquisitions or finding ways to cut redundant processes and costs.”

The digital health sector is in the midst of a major transformation, and M&A activity could be one of the major drivers of this change. Askew believes that the economic downturn could create opportunities for more traditional players to get involved in the space.

“I think that there are going to be a lot of different players involved in digital health M&A in 2021,” Askew said. “It’s going to be an exciting year for the sector, and one that could really shape the industry for years to come.”

Big changes to 401(k) and other retirement savings accounts are on their way in the wake of the pandemic-driven recession.

The Biden administration and Democrats in Congress are expected to target retirement savings for relief efforts, which could include expanding access to retirement savings accounts and incentivizing employers to contribute to them.

The proposal could bring relief to many people struggling to save for retirement, especially those who lost their jobs during the pandemic.

At the same time, it could also benefit employers, who can offer retirement savings accounts as an employee benefit to attract top talent.

The proposed changes could also make a big difference for low- and middle-income savers, who are often locked out of some of the most powerful retirement savings accounts, such as 401(k)s.

Here's a closer look at the changes that could be coming to retirement savings accounts and what they mean for you.

1. Increasing access to 401(k)s

The Biden administration and congressional Democrats are expected to push for legislation to expand access to retirement savings accounts, with 401(k)s in particular getting special attention.

The Biden plan includes several incentives to encourage employers to offer 401(k)s. First, employers will be able to receive a tax credit of up to $1,500 for each employee who signs up for the plan.

Second, the plan proposes allowing employers to automatically enroll employees in 401(k)s, which is currently not allowed under most 401(k) plans.

Finally, the administration has proposed increasing the maximum age for contributions from 70 ½ to 75, meaning people will be able to contribute to their 401(k)s for a longer period of time.

2. Offering tax breaks for retirement savings

The Biden plan also proposes expanding tax breaks for retirement savings. Currently, the federal government provides a tax break for contributions to 401(k)s and other retirement savings accounts.

Under the proposed plan, savers will be able to contribute up to $19,500 to 401(k)s each year, up from the current maximum of $18,000.

The plan also proposes increasing the maximum age for deducting retirement contributions from 70 ½ to 75, giving savers five more years to take advantage of the tax break.

In addition, the plan would increase the tax credits for contributions to retirement savings accounts for low- and middle-income savers.

3. Promoting Employer-sponsored retirement plans

The Biden plan would also promote employer-sponsored retirement plans such as 401(k)s.

Currently, employers can receive a tax credit of up to $500 for each employee who enrolls in a plan. Under the proposed plan, employers will receive a tax credit of up to $1,500 for each employee who enrolls in a plan.

In addition, employers will be able to deduct contributions to 401(k)s and other retirement savings accounts.

Finally, the plan proposes allowing employers to match employee contributions of up to $5,500, making it easier for employers to offer 401(k)s as an employee benefit.

4. More flexible retirement withdrawals

The Biden plan also proposes expanding access to retirement funds by allowing people to withdraw up to $10,000 from their retirement savings accounts without penalty.

Currently, the government only allows penalty-free withdrawals of up to $5,000 for certain expenses, such as education or medical expenses. The proposed plan would expand this to include other expenses, such as buying a home or starting a business.

5. What this means for you

The proposed changes to 401(k)s and other retirement savings accounts could be a boon for low- and middle-income savers, who often struggle to save for retirement.

Expanded access to 401(k)s, increased tax breaks and more flexible withdrawals could make it easier for people to save for retirement.

At the same time, employers could benefit by offering retirement savings plans as an employee benefit, which can help attract top talent.

Ultimately, the proposed changes could make retirement savings easier and more accessible, giving savers the opportunity to build a secure financial future.
